title: Sort Words into Parts of Speech
question: Create an interactive diagram game where students sort words into grammatical categories: nouns (dog, happiness, city), verbs (run, think, become), adjectives (blue, tall, happy), and adverbs (quickly, very, always).

blueprint.title: Grammar Guru: Parts of Speech Sorter
blueprint.subject: English Language Arts (Grammar)
blueprint.narrativeIntro: Welcome, aspiring linguist! Your mission in the Linguistic Lab is to accurately classify words into their fundamental grammatical categories. Precision is key to mastering the building blocks of language!
blueprint.completionMessage: Excellent work, Grammar Guru! You've successfully categorized all the words, demonstrating a strong understanding of parts of speech.

config.instruction_text: Drag each 'Word Item' from the 'Words Pool' into its correct grammatical 'Category Zone' (Noun, Verb, Adjective, or Adverb). Pay attention to how words function in different contexts.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! You've correctly identified the part of speech for this word.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Remember the definition for this category. Think about how the word functions in a sentence.
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic work! You've successfully categorized all the words. Your understanding of parts of speech is strong!

misconceptions.message: Many words can function as different parts of speech depending on how they are used in a sentence (e.g., 'run' can be a verb or a noun). Always consider the word's role in a sentence.

While many adverbs end in '-ly', some adjectives also do (e.g., 'friendly'), and some adverbs do not (e.g., 'very'). Similarly, some words describing nouns can be used adverbially in other contexts. Focus on the word's function.
Nouns include both concrete entities (people, places, tangible things) and abstract concepts (ideas, qualities, feelings). Don't forget abstract nouns!

categories.label: Noun
categories.description: A person, place, thing, or idea.

categories.label: Verb
categories.description: An action or state of being.

categories.label: Adverb
categories.description: Describes or modifies a verb, adjective, or another adverb.

items.explanation: 'River' is a noun because it is a place/thing.
'Jump' is a verb because it describes an action.
'Happy' is an adjective because it describes a noun (e.g., a happy person).
'Quickly' is an adverb because it describes how a verb is done (e.g., he ran quickly).
'Idea' is a noun because it is a concept or thought, which is a 'thing'.
'Analyze' is a verb because it is an action you can perform.
'Enormous' is an adjective because it describes the size of a noun (e.g., an enormous whale).
'Often' is an adverb because it describes the frequency of a verb (e.g., we often go there).
'Happiness' is an abstract noun; it is the name of a feeling or state.
'Is' is a verb that describes a state of being.
Though it ends in '-ly', 'friendly' is an adjective because it describes a noun (e.g., a friendly dog).
'Very' is an adverb because it modifies an adjective (very tall) or another adverb (very quickly).
In this context, 'run' is a thing (an act of running), making it a noun.
items.description: As in: 'She went for a long run.'

items.explanation: Here, 'fast' is an action (to abstain from food), making it a verb.
In this sentence, 'fast' describes the noun 'car', making it an adjective.
items.description: As in: 'He drives a fast car.'

items.explanation: Here, 'fast' describes how she runs (it modifies the verb 'run'), making it an adverb.
'Scientist' is a noun because it is a person.
'Think' is a verb because it is a mental action.
'Blue' is an adjective because it describes a noun (e.g., the blue sky).
'Carefully' is an adverb because it describes how an action is performed (e.g., she listened carefully).
